title: 110_s3070
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Boy Scouts of America Centennial Commemorative Coin Act". The Boy Scouts of America, the largest youth organization in the US, will celebrate its centennial on February 8, 2010. Since 1910, over 111 million youth have participated in its programs. The organization was granted a Federal charter in 1916 by President Woodrow Wilson. In the 110th Congress, 248 members have been involved with the Boy Scouts of America. The Boy Scouts of America's mission is to prepare young people to make ethical choices by instilling values of the Scout Oath and Law. Scouts pledge to uphold these values daily, committing to duty to God and country, helping others, and staying physically strong, mentally awake, and morally straight. In the past 4 years, Scouts have volunteered over 6.5 million hours through 75,000 service projects. In the past 4 years, Scouts have volunteered over 6.5 million hours through more than 75,000 service projects, benefiting food banks, local schools, and civic organizations. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS.

The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue up to 350,000 $1 silver coins to commemorate the Boy Scouts of America centennial. Each coin will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. The coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the 100 years of the Boy Scouts of America. Each coin will feature the coin's value, the year "2010", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Chief Scout Executive and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single designated Mint facility between February 8, 2010, and January 1, 2011. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. Sales of coins under this Act include a $10 surcharge per coin. Surcharges go to the National Boy Scouts of America Foundation for grants to extend Scouting in underserved areas. The Comptroller General can audit the Foundation's expenditures.
